case_vignette: A 27-year-old man presents to the emergency department after an episode of palpitations followed by syncope. He awoke after being unconscious for several seconds but still has a sensation of palpitations. The patient is not currently followed by a primary care doctor but states that he has never had any health problems. His temperature is 98.5°F (36.9°C), blood pressure is 133/91 mmHg, pulse is 95/min, respirations are 19/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. An electrocardiogram (ECG) is performed as seen in Figure A.

I've never had any heart tests done before, and I already mentioned earlier that I haven't experienced any chest pain, shortness of breath, or dizziness now, just the lightheadedness when I fainted.

Great, thank you for clarifying. Based on your symptoms, I would like to consider the possibility of a vasovagal reaction. This is a common cause of fainting, and it can be triggered by a variety of factors such as stress, pain, or even seeing blood. Have you ever experienced anything like this before?

The patient has never experienced any chest pain, shortness of breath, or dizziness since the fainting episode. They report feeling lightheaded at the time of fainting, but deny any other symptoms. The patient has no history of heart problems, panic attacks, thyroid disorders, or seizures. They also deny any recent changes in their diet, exercise, or significant stressors in their personal life. The patient has never had any health problems before and has no family history of abnormal heart rhythms. There is no history of migraines, and the patient denies any specific triggers that could have caused the fainting episode.
